byline.contributor: Patrick Boehler contributed reporting from Hong Kong, and Gardiner Harris from Washington.
byline.original: By JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG

abstract: China is in conflict with United States over how and whether to intensify sanctions against North Korea following North Korea's announcement that it detonated nuclear bomb and plans to launch long-range rocket; China's assistance in obtaining ski resort equipment and other luxury goods for North Korea helps leader Kim Jong-un maintain loyalty among his allies and points to weakness of sanctions.
lead_paragraph: China told a United Nations panel that sanctions barring the sale of luxury goods did not apply because skiing is a “normal activity” in North Korea.

headline.main: To Build a Ski Resort Under U.N. Sanctions, North Korea Turned to China
headline.print_headline: China Keeps Luxury Goods Flowing for North Korea

snippet: China told a United Nations panel that sanctions barring the sale of luxury goods did not apply because skiing is a “normal activity” in North Korea.
